For example, scientists have reported plastic accumulation in the stomachs of [[lantern fish]] which are small filter feeders and are the main prey for commercial fish like [[tuna]] and [[swordfish]].<ref>{{cite journal |laysource=Science News |laydate=1 July 2014 |laysummary=https://www.sciencenews.org/article/plastic-goes-missing-sea |doi=10.1073/pnas.1314705111 |pmid=24982135 |pmc=4104848 |title=Plastic debris in the open ocean |journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences |volume=111 |issue=28 |pages=10239–10244 |year=2014 |last1=Cozar |first1=A. |last2=Echevarria |first2=F. |last3=Gonzalez-Gordillo |first3=J. I. |last4=Irigoien |first4=X. |last5=Ubeda |first5=B. |last6=Hernandez-Leon |first6=S. |last7=Palma |first7=A. T. |last8=Navarro |first8=S. |last9=Garcia-De-Lomas |first9=J. |last10=Ruiz |first10=A. |last11=Fernandez-De-Puelles |first11=M. L. |last12=Duarte |first12=C. M. }}</ref> Microplastics also absorb chemical pollutants that can be transferred into the organism's tissues.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1021/acs.est.5b06280 |pmid=26963589 |title=Chemical Pollutants Sorbed to Ingested Microbeads from Personal Care Products Accumulate in Fish |journal=Environmental Science & Technology |volume=50 |issue=7 |pages=4037–4044 |year=2016 |last1=Wardrop |first1=Peter |last2=Shimeta |first2=Jeff |last3=Nugegoda |first3=Dayanthi |last4=Morrison |first4=Paul D. |last5=Miranda |first5=Ana |last6=Tang |first6=Min |last7=Clarke |first7=Bradley O. }}</ref> Small animals are at risk of reduced food intake due to false satiation and resulting starvation or other physical harm from the microplastics.
A study done at the Argentinean coastline of the [[Rio de la Plata]] [[estuary]], found the presence of microplastics in the guts of 11 species of coastal freshwater fish. These 11 species of fish represented four different feeding habits: [[detritivore]], [[planktivore]], [[omnivore]] and [[ichthyophagous]].<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.marpolbul.2017.06.007 |pmid=28633946 |title=Microplastics in gut contents of coastal freshwater fish from Río de la Plata estuary |journal=Marine Pollution Bulletin |volume=122 |issue=1–2 |pages=85–90 |year=2017 |last1=Pazos |first1=Rocío S. |last2=Maiztegui |first2=Tomás |last3=Colautti |first3=Darío C. |last4=Paracampo |first4=Ariel H. |last5=Gómez |first5=Nora }}</ref> This study is one of the few so far to show the ingestion of microplastics by freshwater organisms.
====Humans==== Fish is a significant source of [[protein]] for the human population, accounting for 6.1% of all protein consumed globally in 2007.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.fao.org/docrep/013/i1820e/i1820e01.pdf|title=The State of World Fisheries and Aquaculture 2010|last=|first=|date=2010|website=|publisher=[[Food and Agriculture Organization]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> The microplastics ingested by fish and crustaceans can be subsequently consumed by humans as the end of the [[food chain]]<ref name="KarbalaeiHWC" />. In a study done at the State University of New York, 18 fish species were sampled and all species showed some level of plastics in their systems.<ref name="GrossmanJan"/><ref name=pmid24972075/> Many additional researchers have found evidence that these fibers had become chemically associated with metals, [[polychlorinated biphenyls]], and other toxic contaminants while in water. The microplastic-metal [[chemical complex|complex]] can then enter humans via consumption.<ref name="GrossmanJan"/>
The primary concern with human health in regards to microplastics is more directed towards the different toxic and carcinogenic chemicals used to make these plastics and what they carry. It has also been thought that microplastics can act as a vector for pathogens as well as heavy metals<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Weis|first=Judith|last2=Andrews|first2=Clinton J|last3=Dyksen|first3=John|last4=Ferrara|first4=Raymond|last5=Gannon|first5=John|last6=Laumbach|first6=Robert J|last7=Lederman|first7=Peter|last8=Lippencott|first8=Robert|last9=Rothman|first9=Nancy|date=2015|title=Human Health Impacts of Microplastics and Nanoplastics|url=https://www.state.nj.us/dep/sab/NJDEP-SAB-PHSC-final-2016.pdf|journal=NJDEP SAB Public Health Standing Committee|volume=|pages=23|via=}}</ref>. More specifically, pregnant women in particular are in danger of causing birth defects to male infants such as anogenital distance, penile width, and testicular descent.<ref name=":9">{{cite journal |doi=10.1098/rstb.2009.0053 |pmid=19528062 |pmc=2873021 |title=Plastics, the environment and human health: Current consensus and future trends |journal=Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences |volume=364 |issue=1526 |pages=2153–2166 |year=2009 |last1=Thompson |first1=R. C. |last2=Moore |first2=C. J. |last3=Vom Saal |first3=F. S. |last4=Swan |first4=S. H. }}</ref> This comes from phthalate exposure and DEHP metabolites that interfere with the development of the male reproductive tract.
BPA is a commonly well-known substance that is an ingredient used to harden plastic that can also cause a wide range of disorders. Cardiovascular disease, type 2 diabetes, and abnormalities in liver enzymes are a few disorders that can arise from even small exposure to this chemical.<ref name=":7">{{cite journal |doi=10.1098/rstb.2009.0053 |pmid=19528062 |pmc=2873021 |title=Plastics, the environment and human health: Current consensus and future trends |journal=Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences |volume=364 |issue=1526 |pages=2153–2166 |year=2009 |last1=Thompson |first1=R. C. |last2=Moore |first2=C. J. |last3=Vom Saal |first3=F. S. |last4=Swan |first4=S. H. }}</ref> Although these effects have been more widely studied than other types of plastics, it is still used in the production of much clothing (polyester).
Another dangerous ingredient is called Tetrabromobisphenol A (TBBPA) which is a flame retardant in many different types of plastics such as those used in microcircuits. This chemical has been linked to disruptions in thyroid hormones balance, pituitary function, and infertility<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.tox.2007.12.009 |pmid=18255212 |title=Endocrine effects of tetrabromobisphenol-A (TBBPA) in Wistar rats as tested in a one-generation reproduction study and a subacute toxicity study |journal=Toxicology |volume=245 |issue=1–2 |pages=76–89 |year=2008 |last1=Van Der Ven |first1=Leo T.M. |last2=Van De Kuil |first2=Ton |last3=Verhoef |first3=Aart |last4=Verwer |first4=Cynthia M. |last5=Lilienthal |first5=Hellmuth |last6=Leonards |first6=Pim E.G. |last7=Schauer |first7=Ute M.D. |last8=Cantón |first8=Rocío F. |last9=Litens |first9=Sabina |last10=De Jong |first10=Frank H. |last11=Visser |first11=Theo J. |last12=Dekant |first12=Wolfgang |last13=Stern |first13=Natalia |last14=Håkansson |first14=Helen |last15=Slob |first15=Wout |last16=Van Den Berg |first16=Martin |last17=Vos |first17=Josephus G. |last18=Piersma |first18=Aldert H. }}</ref>. The endocrine system is affected by TBBPA through disruption of the natural T3 functions with the nuclear suspension in pituitary and thyroid.
Many people can expect to come in contact with various types of microplastics on a daily basis in the aforementioned sources (see sources). However, the average citizen is exposed to microplastics through their various types of food included in a normal diet. For instance: Salt. Researchers in China tested three types of table salt samples available in supermarkets and found the presence of microplastics in all of them. [[Sea salt]] has the highest amounts of microplastics compared to lake salt and rock/well salt.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1021/acs.est.5b03163 |pmid=26486565 |title=Microplastic Pollution in Table Salts from China |journal=Environmental Science & Technology |volume=49 |issue=22 |pages=13622–13627 |year=2015 |last1=Yang |first1=Dongqi |last2=Shi |first2=Huahong |last3=Li |first3=Lan |last4=Li |first4=Jiana |last5=Jabeen |first5=Khalida |last6=Kolandhasamy |first6=Prabhu }}</ref> Sea salt and rock salt which are commonly used table salts in Spain have also been found to contain microplastics.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1038/s41598-017-09128-x |pmid=28819264 |pmc=5561224 |title=Microplastics in Spanish Table Salt |journal=Scientific Reports |volume=7 |issue=1 |pages=8620 |year=2017 |last1=Iñiguez |first1=Maria E. |last2=Conesa |first2=Juan A. |last3=Fullana |first3=Andres }}</ref> The most common type of microplastic found in both these studies was [[Polyethylene terephthalate|polyethylene terephthalate (PET).]]
An example of bioaccumulation in the food chain that leads to human exposure was a study done into the tissue samples of mussels to approximate concentration of microplastics. After research scientists estimate that an average citizen might be exposed to 123 MP articles/year/capita of microplastics through mussel consumption in the UK.<ref name=":5">{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.envpol.2018.02.069 |pmid=29604577 |title=Low levels of microplastics (MP) in wild mussels indicate that MP ingestion by humans is minimal compared to exposure via household fibres fallout during a meal |journal=Environmental Pollution |volume=237 |pages=675–684 |year=2018 |last1=Catarino |first1=Ana I. |last2=MacChia |first2=Valeria |last3=Sanderson |first3=William G. |last4=Thompson |first4=Richard C. |last5=Henry |first5=Theodore B. }}</ref> Considering different diets it was also estimated that the microplastic exposure could go up to 4,620 particles/y/capita in countries with a higher shellfish consumption.<ref name=":5" /> However, it is also important to note that the humans on average are exposed to microplastics more in household dust than consuming mussels.
A 2018 study conducted on eight individuals from Europe and Japan found microplastics in [[human feces]] for the first time. All participants were found positive for at least one type of microplastics after all of them had consumed plastic-wrapped food and drunk water from plastic bottles while six had also eaten seafood. It was noted though that the study was small-sized, preliminary and unable to reveal the true origin of the plastic particles.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/10/23/health/microplastics-human-stool-pollution-intl/index.html |title=Microplastics found in human stools, research finds |first=Rob |last=Picheta |work=[[CNN]] |date=October 23, 2018 |accessdate=October 24, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nationalgeographic.com/environment/2018/10/news-plastics-microplastics-human-feces/?user.testname=none |title=In a first, microplastics found in human poop |first=Laura |last=Parker |work=[[National Geographic]] |date=October 22, 2018 |accessdate=October 24, 2018}}</ref>
===Buoyancy=== Approximately half of the plastic material introduced to the marine environment is [[buoyant]], but fouling by organisms can cause plastic debris to sink to the [[sea floor]], where it may interfere with sediment-dwelling species and sedimental gas exchange processes. Several factors contribute to microplastic’s buoyancy, including the density of the plastic it is composed as well as the size and shape of the microplastic fragments themselves.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1038/srep33882 |pmid=27721460 |pmc=5056413 |title=The effect of particle properties on the depth profile of buoyant plastics in the ocean |journal=Scientific Reports |volume=6 |pages=33882 |year=2016 |last1=Kooi |first1=Merel |last2=Reisser |first2=Julia |last3=Slat |first3=Boyan |last4=Ferrari |first4=Francesco F. |last5=Schmid |first5=Moritz S. |last6=Cunsolo |first6=Serena |last7=Brambini |first7=Roberto |last8=Noble |first8=Kimberly |last9=Sirks |first9=Lys-Anne |last10=Linders |first10=Theo E. W. |last11=Schoeneich-Argent |first11=Rosanna I. |last12=Koelmans |first12=Albert A. }}</ref> Microplastics can also form a buoyant biofilm layer on the ocean’s surface.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.marpolbul.2013.10.007 |title=Microplastic pollution in the surface waters of the Laurentian Great Lakes |journal=Marine Pollution Bulletin |volume=77 |pages=177–182 |year=2013 |last1=Eriksen |first1=Marcus |last2=Mason |first2=Sherri |last3=Wilson |first3=Stiv |last4=Box |first4=Carolyn |last5=Zellers |first5=Ann |last6=Edwards |first6=William |last7=Farley |first7=Hannah |last8=Amato |first8=Stephen }}</ref> Buoyancy changes in relation to ingestion of microplastics have been clearly observed in [[autotrophs]] because the absorption can interfere with [[photosynthesis]] and subsequent gas levels.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.aquabiota.se/en/projects/ecological-ecotoxicological-effects-microplastics-associated-contaminants-aquatic-biota/ |title=Ecological and ecotoxicological effects of microplastics and associated contaminants on aquatic biota |publisher=AquaBiota Water Research }}</ref> However, this issue is of more importance for larger plastic debris. {| class="wikitable" |Plastic Type |Abbreviation |Density (g/cm<sup>3</sup>) |- |Polystyrene |PS |1.04-1.08 |- |Expanded Polystyrene |EPS |0.01-0.04 |- |Low-density Polyethylene |LDPE |0.94-0.98 |- |High-density Polyethylene |HDPE |0.94-0.98 |- |Polyamide |PA |1.13-1.16 |- |Polypropylene |PP |0.85-0.92 |- |Acrylonitrile-butadiene-styrene |ABS |1.04-1.06 |- |Polytetrafluoroethylene |PTFE |2.10-2.30 |- |Cellulose Acetate |CA |1.30 |- |Polycarbonate |PC |1.20-1.22 |- |Polymethyl methacrylate |PMMA |1.16-1.20 |- |Polyvinyl chloride |PVC |1.38-1.41 |- |Polyethylene terephthalate |PET |1.38-1.41 |} <ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.jglr.2014.12.020 |title=Plastic debris in the Laurentian Great Lakes: A review |journal=Journal of Great Lakes Research |volume=41 |pages=9–19 |year=2015 |last1=Driedger |first1=Alexander G.J. |last2=Dürr |first2=Hans H. |last3=Mitchell |first3=Kristen |last4=Van Cappellen |first4=Philippe }}</ref>
===Persistent organic pollutants=== Plastic particles may highly concentrate and transport synthetic organic compounds (e.g. persistent organic pollutants, [[POPs]]), commonly present in the environment and ambient seawater, on their surface through [[adsorption]].<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1021/es0010498 |title=Plastic Resin Pellets as a Transport Medium for Toxic Chemicals in the Marine Environment |journal=Environmental Science & Technology |volume=35 |issue=2 |pages=318–324 |year=2001 |last1=Mato |first1=Yukie |last2=Isobe |first2=Tomohiko |last3=Takada |first3=Hideshige |last4=Kanehiro |first4=Haruyuki |last5=Ohtake |first5=Chiyoko |last6=Kaminuma |first6=Tsuguchika }}</ref> Microplastics can act as carriers for the transfer of POPs from the environment to organisms.<ref name="Derraik2002">{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0025-326X(02)00220-5 |title=The pollution of the marine environment by plastic debris: A review |journal=Marine Pollution Bulletin |volume=44 |issue=9 |pages=842–852 |year=2002 |last1=Derraik |first1=José G.B }}</ref><ref name=pmid19528054>{{cite journal |doi=10.1098/rstb.2008.0284 |pmid=19528054 |pmc=2873017 |title=Transport and release of chemicals from plastics to the environment and to wildlife |journal=Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences |volume=364 |issue=1526 |pages=2027–2045 |year=2009 |last1=Teuten |first1=E. L. |last2=Saquing |first2=J. M. |last3=Knappe |first3=D. R. U. |last4=Barlaz |first4=M. A. |last5=Jonsson |first5=S. |last6=Bjorn |first6=A. |last7=Rowland |first7=S. J. |last8=Thompson |first8=R. C. |last9=Galloway |first9=T. S. |last10=Yamashita |first10=R. |last11=Ochi |first11=D. |last12=Watanuki |first12=Y. |last13=Moore |first13=C. |last14=Viet |first14=P. H. |last15=Tana |first15=T. S. |last16=Prudente |first16=M. |last17=Boonyatumanond |first17=R. |last18=Zakaria |first18=M. P. |last19=Akkhavong |first19=K. |last20=Ogata |first20=Y. |last21=Hirai |first21=H. |last22=Iwasa |first22=S. |last23=Mizukawa |first23=K. |last24=Hagino |first24=Y. |last25=Imamura |first25=A. |last26=Saha |first26=M. |last27=Takada |first27=H. }}</ref>
Additives added to plastics during manufacture may leach out upon ingestion, potentially causing serious harm to the organism. [[Endocrine disruption]] by plastic additives may affect the [[reproductive health]] of humans and wildlife alike.<ref name=pmid19528054/>
Plastics, polymers derived from [[mineral oil]]s, are virtually [[non-biodegradable]]. However, renewable natural polymers are now in development which can be used for the production of biodegradable materials similar to that of oil-based polymers.{{Citation needed|date=April 2018}}
== Where microplastics can be found ==
=== Oceans === There is truly a staggering amount of microplastics in our world’s oceans. Though there is debate over exactly how much microplastic is in the world’s oceans a 2015 study estimated that there was between 93 and 236 thousand metric tons of microplastics in the world’s oceans.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1088/1748-9326/10/12/124006 |title=A global inventory of small floating plastic debris |journal=Environmental Research Letters |volume=10 |issue=12 |pages=124006 |year=2015 |last1=Van Sebille |first1=Erik |last2=Wilcox |first2=Chris |last3=Lebreton |first3=Laurent |last4=Maximenko |first4=Nikolai |last5=Hardesty |first5=Britta Denise |last6=Van Franeker |first6=Jan A. |last7=Eriksen |first7=Marcus |last8=Siegel |first8=David |last9=Galgani |first9=Francois |last10=Law |first10=Kara Lavender }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://blog.nationalgeographic.org/2016/04/04/pesky-plastic-the-true-harm-of-microplastics-in-the-oceans/|title=Pesky plastic: The true harm of microplastics in the oceans – National Geographic Blog|website=blog.nationalgeographic.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-25}}</ref> A study of the distribution of Eastern Pacific Ocean surface plastic debris helps to illustrate how the concentration of plastics in the ocean is on the rise. Though the study admits further research is needed to predict trends in ocean plastic concentration, the study, using data on surface plastic concentration (pieces of plastic km<sup>-2</sup>) from 1972-1985 n=60 and 2002-2012 n=457 within the same plastic accumulation zone, found the mean plastic concentration increase between the two sets of data, including a 10-fold increase of 18,160 to 189,800 pieces of plastic km<sup>-2</sup>.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1021/es4053076 |pmid=24708264 |title=Distribution of Surface Plastic Debris in the Eastern Pacific Ocean from an 11-Year Data Set |journal=Environmental Science & Technology |volume=48 |issue=9 |pages=4732–4738 |year=2014 |last1=Law |first1=Kara Lavender |last2=Morét-Ferguson |first2=Skye E. |last3=Goodwin |first3=Deborah S. |last4=Zettler |first4=Erik R. |last5=Deforce |first5=Emelia |last6=Kukulka |first6=Tobias |last7=Proskurowski |first7=Giora }}</ref> And though this study is based on data of surface plastic concentration, not specifically microplastic, additional research has found microplastics to account for 92% of plastic debris on the ocean’s surface, which adds context to the study.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1007/s00267-017-0947-8 |pmid=29043380 |title=Are We Underestimating Microplastic Contamination in Aquatic Environments? |journal=Environmental Management |volume=61 |issue=1 |pages=1–8 |year=2018 |last1=Conkle |first1=Jeremy L. |last2=Báez Del Valle |first2=Christian D. |last3=Turner |first3=Jeffrey W. }}</ref>
=== Freshwater ecosystems === Though there have only been a few studies of microplastics in freshwater ecosystems, microplastics are being increasingly detected in the world’s aquatic environments.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.envpol.2016.06.074 |pmid=27431693 |title=Microplastics in aquatic environments: Implications for Canadian ecosystems |journal=Environmental Pollution |volume=218 |pages=269–280 |year=2016 |last1=Anderson |first1=Julie C. |last2=Park |first2=Bradley J. |last3=Palace |first3=Vince P. }}</ref> The first study on microplastics in freshwater ecosystems was published in 2011 that found an average of 37.8 fragments per square meter of Lake Huron sediment samples. Additionally, studies have found MP (microplastic) to be present in all of the Great Lakes with an average concentration of 43,000 MP particle km<sup>-2</sup>.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1002/anie.201606957 |pmid=27618688 |title=Microplastic in Aquatic Ecosystems |journal=Angewandte Chemie International Edition |volume=56 |issue=7 |pages=1720–1739 |year=2017 |last1=Ivleva |first1=Natalia P. |last2=Wiesheu |first2=Alexandra C. |last3=Niessner |first3=Reinhard }}</ref> Microplastics have also been detected in freshwater ecosystems outside of the United States. The highest concentration of microplastic ever discovered in a studied freshwater ecosystem was recorded in the Rhine river at 4000 MP particles kg<sup>-1</sup>.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1021/acs.est.7b05367 |pmid=29337537 |pmc=5822217 |title=Microplastic Effect Thresholds for Freshwater Benthic Macroinvertebrates |journal=Environmental Science & Technology |volume=52 |issue=4 |pages=2278–2286 |year=2018 |last1=Redondo-Hasselerharm |first1=Paula E. |last2=Falahudin |first2=Dede |last3=Peeters |first3=Edwin T. H. M. |last4=Koelmans |first4=Albert A. }}</ref>
=== Soil === A substantial portion of microplastics are expected to end up in the world’s soil, yet very little research has been conducted on microplastics in soil.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.3389/fpls.2017.01805 |pmid=29093730 |pmc=5651362 |title=Microplastic Incorporation into Soil in Agroecosystems |journal=Frontiers in Plant Science |volume=8 |pages=1805 |year=2017 |last1=Rillig |first1=Matthias C. |last2=Ingraffia |first2=Rosolino |last3=De Souza Machado |first3=Anderson A. }}</ref> There exists some speculation that fibrous secondary microplastics from washing machines could end up in soil through the failure of water treatment plants to completely filter out all of the microplastic fibers. Furthermore, [[geophagous soil fauna]], such as earthworms, mites, and collembolan could contribute to the amount of secondary microplastic present in soil by converting consumed plastic debris into microplastic via digestive processes. Further research, however, is needed. There is concrete data linking one the use of organic waste materials to synthetic fibers being found in the soil; but most studies on plastics in soil merely report its presence and do not quantify how much there is or where it came from.<ref name=":3" /><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1021/es302011r |pmid=22676039 |title=Microplastic in Terrestrial Ecosystems and the Soil? |journal=Environmental Science & Technology |volume=46 |issue=12 |pages=6453–6454 |year=2012 |last1=Rillig |first1=Matthias C. }}</ref>
=== In the air === Airborne microplastics have been detected in the [[Atmosphere of Earth|atmosphere]], as well as indoors and outdoors. A 2017 study found indoor airborne microfiber concentrations between 1.0–60.0 microfibers per cubic meter (33% of which were found to be microplastics).<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.coesh.2017.10.002 |title=Microplastics in air: Are we breathing it in? |journal=Current Opinion in Environmental Science & Health |volume=1 |pages=1–5 |year=2018 |last1=Gasperi |first1=Johnny |last2=Wright |first2=Stephanie L. |last3=Dris |first3=Rachid |last4=Collard |first4=France |last5=Mandin |first5=Corinne |last6=Guerrouache |first6=Mohamed |last7=Langlois |first7=Valérie |last8=Kelly |first8=Frank J. |last9=Tassin |first9=Bruno }}</ref> Another study looked at microplastic in the street dust of Tehran Iran and found 2649 particles of microplastic within ten samples of street dust, with ranging samples concentrations from 83 particle – 605 particles (+/- 10) per 30.0 g of street dust.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1007/s11356-017-9674-1 |pmid=28707239 |title=Microplastic pollution in deposited urban dust, Tehran metropolis, Iran |journal=Environmental Science and Pollution Research |volume=24 |issue=25 |pages=20360–20371 |year=2017 |last1=Dehghani |first1=Sharareh |last2=Moore |first2=Farid |last3=Akhbarizadeh |first3=Razegheh }}</ref> However, much like freshwater ecosystems and soil, more studies are needed to understand the full impact and significance of airborne microplastics.
== Proposed solutions == Some researchers have proposed incinerating plastics to use as energy, which is known as energy recovery. As opposed to losing the energy from plastics into the atmosphere in [[Landfill|landfills]], this process turns some of the plastics back into energy that can be used. However, as opposed to recycling, this method does not diminish the amount of plastic material that is produced. Therefore, recycling plastics is considered a more efficient solution.<ref name=":9" />
Increasing education through recycling campaigns is another proposed solution for microplastic contamination. While this would be a smaller scale solution, education has been shown to reduce littering, especially in urban environments where there are often large concentrations of plastic waste.<ref name=":9" /> If recycling efforts are increased, a cycle of plastic use and reuse would be created to decrease our waste output and production of new raw materials. In order to achieve this, states would need to employ stronger infrastructure and investment around recycling.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kershaw|first=Peter J.|date=2016|title=Marine Plastic Debris and Microplastics|url=http://ec.europa.eu/environment/marine/good-environmental-status/descriptor-10/pdf/Marine_plastic_debris_and_microplastic_technical_report_advance_copy.pdf|dead-url=No|journal=[[United Nations Environment Programme]]|volume=|pages=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171011052123/http://ec.europa.eu/environment/marine/good-environmental-status/descriptor-10/pdf/Marine_plastic_debris_and_microplastic_technical_report_advance_copy.pdf|archive-date=11 October 2017|via=}}</ref> Some advocate for improving recycling technology to be able to recycle smaller plastics to reduce the need for production of new plastics.<ref name=":9" />
Biodegradation is another possible solution to large amounts of microplastic waste. In this process, microorganisms consume and decompose synthetic polymers with using degrading enzymes.<ref name=":10">{{Cite journal|last=Auta|first=H.S.|last2=Emenike|first2=C.U|last3=Fauziah|first3=S.H|date=May 2017|title=Distribution and importance of microplastics in the marine environment: A review of the sources, fate, effects, and potential solutions|url=|journal=[[Environment International]]|volume=102|pages=165–176|doi=10.1016/j.envint.2017.02.013|pmid=28284818|via=}}</ref> These plastics can then be used in the form of energy and as a source of [[carbon]] once broken down. The microbes could potentially be used to treat sewage wastewater, which would decrease the amount of microplastics that pass through into the surrounding environments.<ref name=":10" />
==Policy and legislation== With increasing awareness of the detrimental effects of microplastics on the environment, groups are now advocating for the removal and ban of microplastics from various products.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.marpolbul.2018.10.001 |title=Reducing marine pollution from single-use plastics (SUPs): A review |journal=Marine Pollution Bulletin |volume=137 |pages=157–171 |year=2018 |last1=Schnurr |first1=Riley E.J. |last2=Alboiu |first2=Vanessa |last3=Chaudhary |first3=Meenakshi |last4=Corbett |first4=Roan A. |last5=Quanz |first5=Meaghan E. |last6=Sankar |first6=Karthikeshwar |last7=Srain |first7=Harveer S. |last8=Thavarajah |first8=Venukasan |last9=Xanthos |first9=Dirk |last10=Walker |first10=Tony R. }}</ref> One such campaign is "Beat the Microbead", which focuses on removing plastics from personal care products.<ref name = "BeattheMicrobead" /> The Adventurers and Scientists for Conservation run the Global Microplastics Initiative, a project to collect water samples to provide scientists with better data about microplastic dispersion in the environment.<ref>{{cite web|title=Global Microplastics Initiative|url=http://www.adventurescientists.org/microplastics.html|publisher=Adventure Scientists|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref> [[UNESCO]] has sponsored research and global assessment programs due to the trans-boundary issue that microplastic pollution constitutes.<ref name="GreenFacts">Morris and Chapman: "Marine Litter", "Green Facts: Facts on Health and the Environment", 2001-2015</ref> These environmental groups will keep pressuring companies to remove plastics from their products in order to maintain healthy ecosystems.<ref>Ross, Philip: "'Microplastics' In Great Lakes Pose 'Very Real Threat' To Humans and Animals", International Business Times, 29 October 2013</ref>
;United States
In the US, some states have taken action to mitigate the negative environmental effects of microplastics.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.marpolbul.2017.02.048 |pmid=28238328 |title=International policies to reduce plastic marine pollution from single-use plastics (plastic bags and microbeads): A review |journal=Marine Pollution Bulletin |volume=118 |issue=1–2 |pages=17–26 |year=2017 |last1=Xanthos |first1=Dirk |last2=Walker |first2=Tony R. }}</ref> Illinois was the first US state to ban cosmetics containing microplastics.<ref name=":9" /> On the national level, the [[Microbead-Free Waters Act 2015]] was enacted after being signed by President [[Barack Obama]] on December 28, 2015. The law bans "rinse-off" cosmetic products that perform an exfoliating function, such as toothpaste or face wash. It does not apply to other products such as household cleaners. The act took effect on July 1, 2017, with respect to manufacturing, and July 1, 2018, with respect to introduction or delivery for introduction into interstate commerce.<ref name="PL114-114">United States. Microbead-Free Waters Act of 2015. {{uspl|114|114}}. Approved 2015-12-28.</ref>
On July 25th, 2018, a microplastic reduction amendment was passed by the U.S. House of Representatives.<ref name=":11">{{Cite web|url=https://www.congress.gov/bill/115th-congress/senate-bill/756/text|title=Text - S.756 - 115th Congress (2017-2018): Save Our Seas Act of 2018|last=Dan|first=Sullivan|date=2018-07-26|website=www.congress.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-09-25}}</ref> The legislation, as part of the Save Our Seas Act designed to combat marine pollution, aims to support the [[NOAA]]'s Marine Debris Program. In particular, the amendment is geared towards promoting NOAA’s Great Lakes Land-Based Marine Debris Action Plan to increase testing, cleanup, and education around plastic pollution in the Great Lakes.<ref name=":11" /> President [[Donald Trump]] signed the re-authorization and amendment bill into effect on October 11, 2018.
'''Japan'''
On June 15th, 2018, the Japanese government passed a bill with the goal of reducing microplastic production and pollution, especially in aquatic environments.<ref name=":12">{{Cite news|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2018/06/15/national/bill-reduce-microplastics-released-environment-passed-japans-upper-house/|title=Bill to reduce microplastics released into the environment passed by Japan’s Upper House|last=|first=|date=15 June 2018|work=[[The Japan Times]]|access-date=25 September 2018}}</ref> Proposed by the Environment Ministry and passed unanimously by the Upper House, this is also the first bill to pass in Japan that is specifically targeted at reducing microplastic production, specifically in the personal care industry with products such as face wash and toothpaste.<ref name=":12" /> This law is revised from previous legislation, which focused on removing plastic marine debris. It also focuses on increasing education and public awareness surrounding recycling and plastic waste.<ref name=":12" /> The Environment Ministry has also proposed a number of recommendations for methods to monitor microplastic quantities in the ocean (Recommendations, 2018).<ref>{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=June 2018|title=Recommendations by Experts on the Required Parameters for Microplastics Monitoring in the Ocean|url=http://www.env.go.jp/en/water/marine_litter/pdf/recommendation.pdf|journal=Ministry of Environment, Japan|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> However, the legislation does not specify any penalties for those who continue manufacturing products with microplastics.<ref name=":12" />
'''United Kingdom'''
The "Environmental Protection (Microbeads) (England) Regulations 2017" law from passed by the UK government bans the production of any rinse-off personal care products (such as exfoliants) containing microbeads.<ref name=":13">{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=2017|title=The Environmental Protection (Microbeads) (England) Regulations 2017|url=http://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/2017/1312/pdfs/uksi_20171312_en.pdf|journal=Cabinet of the United Kingdom|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> This particular law denotes specific penalties when it is not obeyed. Those who do not comply are required to pay a fine. In the event that a fine is not paid, product manufacturers may receive a stop notice, which prevents the manufacturer from continuing production until they have followed regulation preventing the use of microbeads. Criminal proceedings may occur if the stop notice is ignored.<ref name=":13" />
== Action for creating awareness == On April 11, 2013 in order to create awareness, artist [[Maria Cristina Finucci]] founded The [[Garbage patch state]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/new/en/venice/about-this-office/single-view/news/the_garbage_patch_territory_turns_into_a_new_state/#.U71u8fl_u9U|title=The garbage patch territory turns into a new state |publisher=United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization}}</ref> under the patronage of [[UNESCO]] and the Italian Ministry of the Environment.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rivistasitiunesco.it/articolo.php?id_articolo=2073 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714144707/http://www.rivistasitiunesco.it/articolo.php?id_articolo=2073 |archivedate=2014-07-14 |title=Rifiuti diventano stato, Unesco riconosce 'Garbage Patch' |language=it}}</ref>
The [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|U.S. Environmental Protection Agency]] (EPA) launched its "Trash-Free Waters" initiative in 2013 to prevent single-use plastic wastes from ending up in waterways and ultimately the ocean.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.deq.virginia.gov/Portals/0/DEQ/CoastalZoneManagement/EPA_Trash_Free_Waters_Program_Virginia_Marine_Debris_Summit_2013.pdf |title=EPA National Trash Free Waters Program |last1=Benson |first1=Bob |last2=Weiler |first2=Katherine |last3=Crawford |first3=Cara |date=2013-02-27 |publisher=U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) |location=Washington, D.C.|id=Presentation at Virginia Marine Debris Summit, 2013}}</ref> EPA collaborates with the [[United Nations Environment Programme]]–Caribbean Environment Programme (UNEP-CEP) and the [[Peace Corps]] to reduce and also remove trash in the [[Caribbean Sea]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.epa.gov/trash-free-waters/international-initiatives-address-marine-debris |title=International Initiatives to Address Marine Debris |date=2018-04-18 |website=Trash-Free Waters |publisher=EPA}}</ref> EPA has also funded various projects in the [[San Francisco Bay Area]] including one that is aimed at reducing the use of single-use plastics such as disposable cups, spoons and straws, from three [[University of California]] campuses.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.epa.gov/trash-free-waters/trash-free-waters-projects |title=Trash-Free Waters Projects |date=2017-09-27 |publisher=EPA}}</ref>
Additionally, there are many organizations advocating action to counter microplastics and that is spreading microplastic awareness. One such group is the Florida Microplastic Awareness Project (FMAP), a group of volunteers who search for microplastics in coastal water samples.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://sfyl.ifas.ufl.edu/flagler/marine-and-coastal/microplastics/|title=Microplastics - UF/IFAS Extension|last=Communications|first=IFAS|website=sfyl.ifas.ufl.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-09-25}}</ref>
== Cleanup == Computer modelling done by [[The Ocean Cleanup]], a Netherlands foundation, has suggested that collecting devices placed nearer to the coasts could remove about 31% of the microplastics in the area.<ref>{{cite news |last=Connor |first=Steve |date=2016-01-19 |title=How scientists plan to clean up plastic waste in the oceans |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/environment/nature/how-scientists-plan-to-clean-up-the-plastic-waste-threatening-marine-life-a6820276.html |work=The Independent |location=London}}</ref> In addition, [[Marine_debris#Environmental_impact|some bacteria]] have evolved to eat plastic, and some bacteria species have been genetically modified to eat (certain types of) plastics.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://aabgu.org/eating-away-the-worlds-plastic-waste-problem/|title=Eating Away the World's Plastic Waste Problem |date=2017-01-23 |website=News; Natural Sciences |publisher=American Associates, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev |location=New York}}</ref>
On September 9, 2018, The Ocean Cleanup launched the world’s first ocean cleanup system, 001 aka “Wilson”, which is being deployed to the Great Pacific Garbage Patch.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theoceancleanup.com/updates/system-001-has-launched-into-the-pacific/|title=System 001 has launched into the Pacific|last=www.theoceancleanup.com|first=The Ocean Cleanup,|work=The Ocean Cleanup|access-date=2018-09-25|language=en-EN}}</ref> System 001 is 600 meters long that acts as a U-shaped skiff that uses natural oceanic currents to concentrate plastic and other debris on the ocean’s surface into a confined area for extraction by vessels.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theoceancleanup.com/technology/|title=The Ocean Cleanup Technology|last=www.theoceancleanup.com|first=The Ocean Cleanup|website=The Ocean Cleanup|language=en|access-date=2018-09-25}}</ref> The project has been met with criticism from oceanographers and plastic pollution experts, though it has seen wide public support.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.deepseanews.com/2014/07/the-ocean-cleanup-part-2-technical-review-of-the-feasibility-study/|title=The Ocean Cleanup, Part 2: Technical review of the feasibility study|last=Martini|first=Kim|last2=Goldstein|first2=Miriam|date=14 July 2014|website=Deep Sea News|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.southernfriedscience.com/i-asked-15-ocean-plastic-pollution-experts-about-the-ocean-cleanup-project-and-they-have-concerns/|title=I asked 15 ocean plastic pollution experts about the Ocean Cleanup project, and they have concerns|last=Shiffman|first=David|date=13 June 2018|website=Southern Fried Science|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/mar/26/ocean-cleanup-project-environment-pollution-boyan-slat|title=Too good to be true? The Ocean Cleanup Project faces feasibility questions|last=Kratochwill|first=Lindsey|date=26 March 2016|work=[[The Guardian]]|access-date=}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Bioaccumulation]] * [[Biodegradable plastic]] * [[Biodegradation]] * [[Endocrine disruptor|Endocrine disruption]] * [[Great Pacific garbage patch]] * [[Marine debris]] * [[Microbead]] * [[Microfiber]]s * [[The Ocean Cleanup|Ocean Cleanup]] * [[Plastic pollution]] * [[Plastic recycling]] * [[Plastic resin pellet pollution]]

== Further reading == {{Refbegin}} *{{cite book |last1= Blair Crawford |first1= Christopher |last2= Quinn |first2= Brian |year= 2017 |title= Microplastic Pollutants |edition=1st |publisher=Elsevier Science |isbn=978-0-12-809406-8}} *{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.watres.2015.02.012 |pmid=25746963 |title=Microplastics in freshwater systems: A review of the emerging threats, identification of knowledge gaps and prioritisation of research needs |journal=Water Research |volume=75 |pages=63–82 |year=2015 |last1=Eerkes-Medrano |first1=Dafne |last2=Thompson |first2=Richard C. |last3=Aldridge |first3=David C. }} *{{cite publication |last=Lusher|first=Amy|last2=Hollman|first2=Peter |last3=Mendoza-Hill|first3=Jeremy |title=Microplastics in fisheries and aquaculture: status of knowledge on their occurrence and implications for aquatic organisms and food safety |url=http://www.fao.org/3/a-i7677e.pdf |series=FAO Fisheries and Aquaculture Technical Paper Nr. 615 |publisher=Food and Agriculture Organzation (FAO) |location=Rome |year=2017 |ISSN=2070-7010|format=pdf|language=en}} *{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.trac.2014.10.011 |title=A critical overview of the analytical approaches to the occurrence, the fate and the behavior of microplastics in the environment |journal=Trac Trends in Analytical Chemistry |volume=65 |pages=47–53 |year=2015 |last1=Rocha-Santos |first1=Teresa |last2=Duarte |first2=Armando C. }} *{{cite journal |doi=10.1186/s12302-014-0012-7 |pmid=28936382 |pmc=5566174 |title=Microplastics in freshwater ecosystems: What we know and what we need to know |journal=Environmental Sciences Europe |volume=26 |issue=1 |pages=12 |year=2014 |last1=Wagner |first1=Martin |last2=Scherer |first2=Christian |last3=Alvarez-Muñoz |first3=Diana |last4=Brennholt |first4=Nicole |last5=Bourrain |first5=Xavier |last6=Buchinger |first6=Sebastian |last7=Fries |first7=Elke |last8=Grosbois |first8=Cécile |last9=Klasmeier |first9=Jörg |last10=Marti |first10=Teresa |last11=Rodriguez-Mozaz |first11=Sara |last12=Urbatzka |first12=Ralph |last13=Vethaak |first13=A Dick |last14=Winther-Nielsen |first14=Margrethe |last15=Reifferscheid |first15=Georg }} {{Refend}}

Charles Moore on the seas of plastic] – video at TED.com *[http://www.pelletwatch.org/ International Pellet Watch]
===News=== * "[https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2018/mar/12/microplastic-pollution-in-oceans-is-far-greater-than-thought-say-scientists Microplastic pollution in oceans is far worse than feared, say scientists]," ''The Guardian,'' March 2018 * "[https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2017/sep/08/our-plastic-addiction-out-of-control-cut-consumption-now Q&A: our plastic addiction is out of control. How can we consume less?]," ''The Guardian,'' September 2017 * "[https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2017/sep/06/we-are-living-on-a-plastic-planet-what-does-it-mean-for-our-health We are living on a plastic planet. What does it mean for our health?]," ''The Guardian,'' September 2017 * "[https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2017/sep/06/plastic-fibres-found-tap-water-around-world-study-reveals Plastic fibers found in tap water around the world, study reveals]," ''The Guardian,'' September 2017 * "[https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2007/10/071029092034.htm 'Microplastics' May Pose Previously Unrecognized Pollution Threat]," ''Science Daily,'' November 2007
===Films=== * [http://www.plastic-planet.de/ ''Plastic Planet''], Werner Boote and Gerhard Pretting * {{YouTube|B_rS1WJL6so|Addicted To Plastic}} * ''Addicted to Plastic'' at [http://www.bullfrogfilms.com/catalog/atp.html Bullfrog Films] and at [http://www.crypticmoth.com/plastic.php Cryptic Moth] * {{YouTube|dfcRW7sIrPI|Plasticized}} * {{YouTube|d8R1pRMLbg0|The problem with microplastics}}
